docs.lead_paragraph: When Mike Kreidler was an optometrist in Olympia, Wash., he railed against trial lawyers. He believed that aggressive trial lawyers were the reason he faced rising insurance premiums. Dr. Kreidler, now in his second term as Washington State's insurance commissioner, has changed his mind. He has decided that the problem is not the lawyers -- although they have contributed -- but also the insurance companies.

headline.main: Study Says Malpractice Payouts Aren't Rising

docs.abstract: Study to be released by Center for Justice and Democracy, consumer advocacy group, finds net claims for medical malpractice paid by 15 leading insurance companies have remained flat over last five years, while net premiums have surged 120 percent; from 2000 to 2004, increase in premiums collected by leading 15 medical malpractice insurance companies was 21 times increase in claims they paid (M)
docs.snippet: The study finds that net claims for medical malpractice paid by 15 leading insurance companies have remained flat.

docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, the nation's second-largest health insurer, made a big push into the rapidly growing Medicare market yesterday by agreeing to buy PacifiCare Health Systems for $8.14 billion in cash and stock. By adding PacifiCare's 3.3 million enrollees, UnitedHealth will have 25.7 million members. That would make it a bigger competitor to the leader in health insurance, WellPoint, which has 27.7 million members and was created by last year's $16.5 billion merger of WellPoint and Anthem.

headline.main: UnitedHealth to Buy PacifiCare in Push Into Medicare

docs.abstract: UnitedHealth Group makes big push into rapidly growing Medicare market by agreeing to buy PacifiCare Health Systems for $8.14 billion in cash and stock; PacifiCare will operate as wholly owned unit of UnitedHealth if shareholders and state and federal regulators approve deal; UnitedHealth's chief executive Dr William McGuire comments; graph (M)
docs.snippet: UnitedHealth Group made a big push into the rapidly growing Medicare market by agreeing to buy PacifiCare Health Systems for $8.14 billion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Takeover Bid for Unocal Is About Business, Says the Chairman of Its Chinese Suitor Fu Chengyu, chairman of Cnooc Ltd., says profits, not politics, are behind his company's $18.5 billion proposal to buy Unocal, China's most ambitious takeover bid. ''I have no talent for politics,'' he said, ''only business.'' [Page A1.] UnitedHealth to Buy PacifiCare for $8.14 Billion The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's second-largest health insurer, made a big push into the rapidly growing Medicare market by agreeing to buy PacifiCare Health Systems for $8.14 billion in cash and stock. [C1.] Boeing Sets Pay for Chief Executive The aircraft maker Boeing has agreed to pay its new chief executive, W. James McNerney Jr., total compensation that could top $53 million to wrest him away from 3M. [C1.] Charting the Cost of Malpractice Insurance In a study that may add fuel to the debate over the high price of medical malpractice insurance, the Center for Justice and Democracy found that net claims paid by 15 leading insurance companies stayed flat over the last five years, while net premiums surged 120 percent. [C1.] Food Companies Strike Back Against Obesity Suits Food and restaurant companies, fearing enormous judgments like those that hammered the tobacco industry, are fighting back against attempts to sue them for causing obesity or obesity-related health problems. [C1.] Microsoft and French Partner Detail Alliance The chief executives of Microsoft and France Télécom fleshed out the details of an alliance announced at the end of June. Steve Ballmer of Microsoft, near left, said two products under development were a mobile phone with Wi-Fi wireless capability, and a device with cellular, Wi-Fi and voice-over-Internet protocol technologies. Didier Lombard of France Télécom, far left, said another possibility raised was an updated Minitel, France's precursor to the Internet. [C3.] A Corporate Pitchman May Return to TV Chrysler is bringing back Lee A. Iacocca to do what he does best -- pitch cars in commercials. At least that is the plan. Chrysler executives said a deal was being negotiated with Mr. Iacocca, the company's 80-year-old retired chairman. The first of three commercials has already been shot. Advertising. [C1.] Actor Has Lead in Movie Download Venture A production company that is backed by Intel and counts Morgan Freeman, the actor, as an owner is forming a venture to sell movie downloads on the Internet. The new company, ClickStar, hopes to offer movies on the same day that they begin showing in theaters. [C6.] Utah Bank to Enter Texas With $1.7 Billion Deal Zions Bancorp, a Salt Lake City bank founded by the Mormon Church, has agreed to buy Amegy Bancorp for $1.7 billion to extend its eight-state, 400-branch network into Texas. Amegy investors will receive cash or stock valued at $23.32 a share, the companies said. Zions traces its roots to 1873, when the Mormon leader Brigham Young created the Zions Savings Bank and Trust Company. [C11.] Weather Roils Crude Oil Market Crude oil prices surged above $61 a barrel after a tropical storm curbed production in the Gulf of Mexico and forced the evacuation of offshore operations. Oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange reached $61.35 a barrel, then closed at $61.28, up $1.69. Market Place. [C3.] Stocks fell as oil prices caused investors to look past a report showing strong growth in the service sector. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 101.12 points, to 10,270.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 10.05 points, at 1,194.94, and the Nasdaq lost 10.10 points, to 2,068.65. [C11.] General Electric in Aircraft Financing Deal The CIT Group said it agreed to sell nearly $1 billion of corporate aircraft leases and loans to General Electric. [C17.] A.I.G. Executive to Oversee Reinsurance The American International Group, the insurer sued by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, over suspected improper reinsurance accounting, appointed an executive to oversee its reinsurance relationships. [C3.] Scandal Ripples Beyond Volkswagen A rapidly expanding bribery and corruption scandal at Volkswagen threatens one of Germany's most prominent corporate executives and could harm Chancellor Gerhard Schröder. [C4.] Cellphones That Carry a Tune The cellphone has acquired several new features in recent years, from text messaging to video. Now cellphone makers and wireless operators are shifting their attention to music. Circuits. [C9.]

docs.lead_paragraph: L. Patrick Gray III, the former acting director of the F.B.I. whose misplaced trust in Richard M. Nixon and early missteps in handling the Watergate investigation made him a lasting victim of a scandal he ultimately helped to expose, died yesterday at his home in Atlantic Beach, Fla. He was 88. The cause was complications of pancreatic cancer, his family said.

headline.main: L. Patrick Gray III, 88, Acting Director Of the F.B.I. During Watergate, Dies

docs.snippet: L. Patrick Gray III's early missteps in handling the Watergate investigation made him a victim of a scandal he ultimately helped to expose.

multimedia.credit: L. Patrick Gray, who served as acting F.B.I. director while his deputy leaked information that led to President Nixon's resignation, was 88.
multimedia.caption: Watergate Figure Dies

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: L. Patrick Gray, who served as acting F.B.I. director while his deputy leaked information that led to President Nixon's resignation, was 88.

docs.lead_paragraph: In 2001, officials in charge of New Jersey's state medical school were warned by its lawyer that the school's clinics overcharged Medicaid more than $1 million in the previous year, and that its billing practices since the mid-1990's were probably illegal. Under that practice, the university billed Medicaid for its doctors' services to patients as the doctors were billing Medicaid for the same services. Despite the warning, and a similar one from the university's chief financial officer a year later, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey continued to allow the double billing for more than three years after the first warning. One former university official, Adam Henick, a vice president who reviewed the billings, estimated that an additional $5 million was billed improperly to Medicaid during that period.

headline.main: Medical School Double-Billed U.S. for Years

docs.snippet: New Jersey's state medical school billed Medicaid for its doctors' services to patients as the doctors were billing Medicaid for the same services.

byline.original: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI and JOHN SULLIVAN; Richard Perez-Pena contributed reporting for this article

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical device makers devote years and millions of dollars to winning regulatory approval for new products. But all that work does not necessarily produce the kind of data that persuades insurers to pay for the products once they hit the market. Take what has happened since the Food and Drug Administration gave Johnson & Johnson clearance last fall to sell an implantable spinal disk called the Charité (shar-ee-TAY).

headline.main: When F.D.A. Says Yes, but Insurers Say No

docs.snippet: The work that medical device makers put into winning approval for new products does not necessarily persuade insurers to pay for them once they hit the market.

docs.lead_paragraph: St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, the largest Catholic hospital system in New York State, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday morning, citing years of mounting debts and falling revenues. St. Vincent officials said that services at the center's seven hospitals and other health care facilities would not be affected by the Chapter 11 filing, and that no job cuts were planned. Within the past year, however, the St. Vincent system has been forced to close one hospital -- St. Joseph's in Flushing, Queens -- and to begin the process of closing two more, Bayley Seton on Staten Island and St. Mary's in Brooklyn.

headline.main: St. Vincent Medical Centers System Files for Bankruptcy

docs.snippet: The largest Catholic hospital system in New York State filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday morning, citing years of mounting debts and falling revenues.

docs.lead_paragraph: DRIVING to a memorial service for his mother one day in late 2000, Alex Briscoe took a wrong turn into the flat, forgotten streets of west Oakland, finally idling his motor outside McClymonds High School. He saw a teenager smoking marijuana on the front lawn until a security guard gave chase. He noticed the razor wire around the perimeter. Even as an educator who had worked in South Philadelphia, no place for the naïve, Mr. Briscoe asked himself, ''How can this be?'' McClymonds ranked by any measure among the worst handful of high schools in the entire state. Barely a fifth of entering ninth graders lasted until graduation. Virtually none of those survivors could qualify for admission to the University of California system. Just a few months earlier, an 18-year-old senior, Khadafy Washington, had been shot and left to die on the school playground.

headline.main: Easing Troubled Emotions Inside a Troubled School

docs.snippet: Providing a professional mental health clinic helped one high school in Oakland, Calif., reach its students.
